column1: At Amazon, we are committed to providing a transparent performance feedback
process. Below you have an opportunity to view and interact with your recent
feedback using the Message and Files tabs.
On October 8, 2025 you were involved in a Lock Out Tag Out incident. During
the course of this action, you failed to wear PPE and follow Lock Out Tag
Out guidelines by opening the left (input side) door of the station while
the equipment remained energized. A seek to understand conversation took
place with you on October 8, 2025 to which you stated, “I pushed the e-stop’
but that you were not going to take your time to read through the procedure
posted. This is considered a Category 1 safety violation: Disregarding the
Hazardous Energy Control Policy (Lock Out Tag Out); for example failure to
lock out/tag out equipment when required, or performing live electrical work
without the properly completed energized electrical work permit. This
at-risk behavior could result in serious injury or loss of life. Violations
of safety guidelines puts yourself and others at risk for danger.
Amazon is committed to providing a safe working environment for all
associates, and it is every associate’s responsibility to work in a safe,
responsible manner identifying unsafe situations to management immediately.
Failure to adhere to all Amazon behavioral expectations, including the
expectations stated in this feedback, may result in extending the timeline
of corrective action or additional corrective action up to and including
termination of employment. This feedback will remain active and eligible for
By the way - it's literally against policy to discipline a technician that
But that'll be in the report.
You don't have to, but if you can and are willing, please help me in fixing
this systemic problem within our culture at Amazon RME - because all I want
to do is move forward without having any further obstacles needlessly and
Btw - last week I met with Sara - she didnt seem very responsive to my
suggestions that True Leadership and Effective Communication would fix 99%
of our collective issues in RME, including her metrics.
I know not what else to do except reach out to you with this email before I
file the official appeal, file with the ethics line, inform OSHA via
messages that one day they may receieve if the Gov ever reopens, and speak
to other salaried Amazonians who perhaps will take the initiative.
I have borne the weight because I can, but nobody should have to.

column1: At Amazon, we are committed to providing a transparent performance feedback
process. Below you have an opportunity to view and interact with your recent

On October 8, 2025 you were involved in a Lock Out Tag Out incident. During
the course of this action, you failed to wear PPE and follow Lock Out Tag
Out guidelines by opening the left (input side) door of the station while
the equipment remained energized. A seek to understand conversation took
place with you on October 8, 2025 to which you stated, “I pushed the e-stop’
but that you were not going to take your time to read through the procedure
posted. This is considered a Category 1 safety violation: Disregarding the
Hazardous Energy Control Policy (Lock Out Tag Out); for example failure to
lock out/tag out equipment when required, or performing live electrical work
without the properly completed energized electrical work permit. This
at-risk behavior could result in serious injury or loss of life. Violations
of safety guidelines puts yourself and others at risk for danger.
Amazon is committed to providing a safe working environment for all
associates, and it is every associate’s responsibility to work in a safe,
responsible manner identifying unsafe situations to management immediately.
Failure to adhere to all Amazon behavioral expectations, including the
expectations stated in this feedback, may result in extending the timeline
of corrective action or additional corrective action up to and including
termination of employment. This feedback will remain active and eligible for
By the way - it's literally against policy to discipline a technician that
But that'll be in the report.

Btw - last week I met with Sara - she didnt seem very responsive to my

I have borne the weight because I can, but nobody should have to.

Despite this, the APM  system auto-generated and assigned 14 Priority 5 preventive maintenance work orders  to a single technician (ERWOMACK). When these could not be executed due to freeze compliance and mandatory meetings, management issued performance reprimands rather than recognizing the systemic contradiction. Independent analyses from both Amazon Q  and Cedric (Internal Compliance AI)  have verified the event chain as a policy-system synchronization failure , not technician negligence. 2 | Policy Context Global PMO Code Freeze Policy:  Defines Advisory, Restricted, and Blocked days requiring multi-level approvals (L7 → L8 → Customer L8). Scope:  Applies to all RME design, software, and maintenance changes during peak. Intent:  Preserve operational stability during Prime Day. Conflict:  APM scheduler does not ingest PMO freeze calendar metadata. 3 | Event Timeline (10 / 7 / 2025) Time Event Impact 04 : 30 – 08 : 00 No PMs visible No actionable tasks 08 : 15 14 PMs auto-assigned Violation of Code Freeze logic 08 : 23 Summoned by @Nate Hendricks for training Removed from floor 09 : 00 – 13 : 30 Meetings with Sara (RM) and Jon 4 + hours non-productive 14 : 50 – 15 : 10 Reprimand from Ryan Truax Misinterpretation of metrics Total hours lost to mandatory meetings/training:  ≈ 6 hrs Available time for execution:  < 2 hrs Number of PMs:  14 (non-critical) 4 | Ownership and Escalation Matrix Cross-Check According to Ownership and Escalation v05-18-2021.xlsx : L5/L6 Area Managers  must verify policy alignment before disciplinary coaching. L7 Regional Manager  must escalate any policy versus system conflict to OTS Central. L8 OTS Leaders  are final arbiters for Blocked Days. No escalation occurred. The reprimand was issued in violation of this matrix. 5 | Independent Analyses Amazon Q Summary APM auto-scheduled 14 open PMs within freeze window. Systemic mismatch between PMO policy and scheduler logic. Recommendation: Integrate freeze metadata into APM and align managerial KPIs with policy compliance. Cedric (Confidential Internal AI) Summary Managerial language constituted potential harassment and bias. Performance evaluation was procedurally flawed. Recommended escalation to HR to ensure due process and prevent retaliation. 6 | Key Findings Policy Violation:  Work orders scheduled during Blocked period contradict global freeze protocol. Managerial Misconduct:  Reprimand issued without fact-finding or policy context. Escalation Failure:  Ownership matrix steps (L5 → L7) ignored. System Defect:  APM lacks policy metadata synchronization. Cultural Deficiency:  Metrics prioritized over compliance and technician well-being. 7 | Recommendations for HR and Leadership Immediate HR Review:  Investigate managerial conduct for potential harassment and procedural violations. Policy Integration:  Mandate APM ↔ PMO metadata link to auto-suspend non-critical PMs during freeze. Managerial Training:  Re-educate L5 + L6 leaders on Ownership and Escalation matrix and context-aware evaluation. Compliance Audit:  Request OTS/PMO review of TPA4 for adherence to freeze policy and escalation standards. Protection from Retaliation:  Confirm ERWOMACK is covered under Amazon’s Zero Retaliation Policy pending investigation. 8 | Attachments NA USA & CA – Prime Big Deal Days RME Code Freeze Announcement.eml Ownership and Escalation v05-18-2021.xlsx Slack conversation with Ryan Truax (10-7-2025) Q and Cedric AI analysis transcripts APM Work Order Report (ARSTOW PMs Oct 9–14 2025) Prepared and submitted in good faith for review under Amazon’s Standards of Conduct and Zero Retaliation Policy. — Ethan Womack (ERWOMACK) Here's the pasted slack exchange at the end of my day between Ryan (AMM) and Jon (MM) - I spoke today with Sara Wright about the effects of "ineffective communication" between management - operations - and especially new techs"  @Bonanno, Jessi  I'm going to add you to the actually slack thread because ...  I don't want anything to disappear.  " Jon Templeton, Ryan Truax 3 Messages Untitled CanvasListFolder This is the very beginning of your direct message history with @templetj  and @ryantrua You’ll be notified for every new message  in this conversation. Change this setting Ryan Truax  2:50 PM All PMs were assigned by 0815 we can verify that via Audit trail. Men as Allies | Program Manager: Jamillah Smith
In July, the Men as Allies program held in Dallas welcomed 23 RME leaders.
The session received an impressive Net Promoter Score (NPS) of 86 and an
overall participant satisfaction score of 4.6 out of 5.
Looking ahead to the upcoming session in September, were aiming to have
44 men from RME participate, nearly doubling our previous attendance.
| NA Manager Onboarding I Program Manager: Taylor Molden, Deirdre Iadarola
In August, NA RME Manager Onboarding continued to strengthen our
leadership foundation with two sessions in the great state of Texas in
Austin and Dallas. We welcomed 39 managers to this comprehensive 3-day
program. The impressive satisfaction score of 4.7 reflects the
high-quality content and engaging experience we've created for our new
leaders. Each participant shared their unique experiences, contributing to
rich discussions and valuable peer connections. Additionally, we were
fortunate to be joined by two L8 leaders within the organization who
shared valuable perspectives throughout the courses.
We look forward to seeing these new leaders utilize their new skills and
knowledge to lead their teams effectively.

Nashville for transformative sessions this past August and September. The
energy and enthusiasm were truly contagious as participants connected with
their mentors, shared experiences, and supported each other's leadership
Through engaging workshops, candid conversations, and meaningful
networking opportunities, these talented professionals developed new
skills and mapped out their paths to leadership success.
The incredible feedback we received, including an outstanding Net Promoter
Score of 82, tells us that our community of emerging women leaders found
real value in their experience. It's been amazing to witness the bonds
formed, the confidence built, and the goals set during these powerful
sessions. We can't wait to see how these exceptional women will continue
Men as Allies | Program Manager: Jamillah Smith
In July, the Men as Allies program held in Dallas welcomed 23 RME leaders.
The session received an impressive Net Promoter Score (NPS) of 86 and an
overall participant satisfaction score of 4.6 out of 5.
Looking ahead to the upcoming session in September, were aiming to have
44 men from RME participate, nearly doubling our previous attendance.
| NA Manager Onboarding I Program Manager: Taylor Molden, Deirdre Iadarola
In August, NA RME Manager Onboarding continued to strengthen our
leadership foundation with two sessions in the great state of Texas in
Austin and Dallas. We welcomed 39 managers to this comprehensive 3-day
program. The impressive satisfaction score of 4.7 reflects the
high-quality content and engaging experience we've created for our new
leaders. Each participant shared their unique experiences, contributing to
rich discussions and valuable peer connections. Additionally, we were
fortunate to be joined by two L8 leaders within the organization who
shared valuable perspectives throughout the courses.
We look forward to seeing these new leaders utilize their new skills and
knowledge to lead their teams effectively.
Aspiring Leaders Program   | Program Manager: Brandy Lovings
Our Aspiring Leaders Program continues to make waves as we empower the
We're proud to share that 203 of our Level 4 Blue Badge employees have
already completed the engaging two-day virtual sessions, with each
participant bringing their unique perspectives and enthusiasm to the
experience. The program's impressive Net Promoter Score of 78 reflects
just how meaningful these sessions have been for our future leaders. As we
approach our final two sessions scheduled for September 17 and October 1,
we're energized by the connections made, the insights shared, and the
leadership potential unleashed throughout this journey. It's incredible to
see our participants embrace this opportunity for growth and development,
building the skills and confidence they need to take their careers to the
next level. We can't wait to welcome our final groups and complete this

Welcome Srideep Sarkar! In mid-August 2025, they embarked on a tailored 12-week leadership learning pathway.   This program delivers 24 hours of blended learning through interactive facilitator-led sessions, self-paced modules, structured virtual check-ins, and hands-on application challenges all carefully designed to strengthen leadership capabilities within the unique context of an advanced robotics environment.   Brenda Abarabar, PM from the RME Leadership Development team says, This project is exciting as its a great example of how we work with business leaders to deliver customized interventions that begin with a thorough assessment of leadership competency gaps then modify proven training content to deliver optimal learning outcomes for every team.   Click here to submit a Continuous learning facilitation request if you need us to look at creating a customized leadership development program for your team. We'll work with you to design training that meets your specific needs.           W omens Leadership Program | Program Manager: Jamillah Smith     We're thrilled to celebrate another inspiring year of our RME Women Leadership Program, where 28 remarkable women came together in Austin and Nashville for transformative sessions this past August and September. Each participant shared their unique experiences, contributing to rich discussions and valuable peer connections. 20251102131509-message-1-59.eml,"Wed, 15 Oct 2025 08:31:47 -0500","""Womack, Ethan""","""Wilson, Tori""",,,HR - APPEAL,"Based on the information I've found, I can help you understand the LOTO
policies and provide guidance for your appeal. Here's what I discovered:
The policy you referenced appears to be correct. According to Amazon's
documentation, **inadequate LOTO situations are reported as \""Near Miss\""
incidents in the Austin tool, not as disciplinary actions**. The policy
states that when LOTO is determined to be inadequate, managers are
responsible for reporting it as a near miss and including root causes.

P {margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0;} Based on the information I've found, I can help you understand the LOTO policies and provide guidance for your appeal. Here's what I discovered:    ## Key Policy Findings    ### LOTO Failed Audit Policy  The policy you referenced appears to be correct. According to Amazon's documentation, **inadequate LOTO situations are reported as \"Near Miss\" incidents in the Austin tool, not as disciplinary actions**. The policy states that when LOTO is determined to be inadequate, managers are responsible for reporting it as a near miss and including root causes.    ### ARSAW Door Procedures  Regarding ARSAW jam clearing, the documentation shows there are **specific training requirements and procedures for different doors**:    - **VRC Interlock Door**: Requires special certification for Area Managers and Process Assistants to clear jams with jam poles, ensuring the body never crosses the plane of the machine  - **Destacker Interlock Door**: Has separate signage requirements and procedures  - The training distinguishes between different door types and requires specific modules (112786-Dematic, 112787-Intelligrated, or 112788-Vanderlande)    ### Appeal Process  You do have options for appealing disciplinary actions:    - **Timeline**: You have 7 calendar days from the date of corrective action to initiate an appeal  - **Eligibility**: Final Written Warnings are generally eligible for appeal  - **Process**: The Appeals Process allows associates to have claims heard by either a majority associate panel or site leader    ## Supporting Evidence for Your Appeal    ### 1. LOTO Audit vs. Violation Distinction  The documentation supports your position that **failed LOTO audits should be treated as near misses, not disciplinary violations**. Multiple sources confirm that inadequate LOTO situations are reported as near misses in Austin.    ### 2. Training and Procedure Gaps  The extensive documentation on ARSAW training requirements suggests that if you weren't properly trained on the specific procedures for different door types, this could support your case about inadequate training rather than willful violation.    ### 3. Procedural Issues  Your account suggests you were following procedures shown by senior technicians and were interrupted before completing the proper LOTO process, which could indicate a training/procedural issue rather than a safety violation.    ## Recommended Next Steps    1. **File your appeal within 7 days** of receiving the Final Written Warning  2. **Reference the policy distinction** between LOTO audit failures (near miss) vs. violations (disciplinary action)  3. **Document the training gaps** regarding specific ARSAW door procedures  4. **Emphasize the procedural interruption** that prevented you from completing proper LOTO  5. **Request proper training** rather than disciplinary action    The documentation suggests your situation may have been misclassified as a disciplinary violation when it should have been handled as a training/procedural issue and reported as a near miss.    Would you like me to help you draft specific language for your appeal based on these policy findings?    Sources:    [1] DCC.STD.009 Hazardous Energy Control  https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWSHealthandSafety/ManagementSystem/SMPDocuments/WikiSMPDocs/HazardousEnergy/     [2] ARSAW VRC Interlock Door Jam Clearing Training  https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/FTW6-Change-Announcements/Learning/ARSAW_VRC_Interlock_Door_Jam_Clearing_Training/     [3] AFW5 HR MANAGER GUIDE  https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AFW5_HR_MANAGER_GUIDE/     [4] BTR9 HR Manager Guide  https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/BTR9_HR_Manager_Guide/     [5] KUL DCC Localizations  https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWSHealthandSafety/ManagementSystem/SMPDocuments/SMPLocalizations/KULLocs/     [6] AKL DCC Localizations  https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWSHealthandSafety/ManagementSystem/SMPDocuments/SMPLocalizations/AKLLocs/     --- I also would  like to file a harassment claim - A retaliation claim - An obstruction of policy and process claim - And whatever else will add to the truck load of documented evidence I have for the OSHA Whistleblower Investigator when the Government Shutdown ends and things return to normal.  This should be sufficient to serve as the official Appeal however, as the form in AtoZ would not allow for me to upload the documents - I can provide it all if needed upon request.  Thank you. P {margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0;} Case Number  : 20251015-1662164 Ethics Line filing for retaliation Ethan Ross Womack RME Robotics / Mechatronics Technician – Operations Amazon TPA4 – North America Operations 📧 erwomack@amazon.com 📞 +1 (352) 252-0033 💬 Slack | Teams | @ ERWomack 🌐 inside.amazon.com From: Bonanno, Jessi <jesbon@amazon.com> Sent: Wednesday, October 8, 2025 9:06 PM To: Womack, Ethan <erwomack@amazon.com>; Smith, Jena <jenasmit@amazon.com>; Wilson, Tori <vctwils@amazon.com> Cc: Wright, Sara <saracw@amazon.com> Subject: Re: Formal Escalation: Code Freeze Policy Violation / Managerial Misconduct / RME-PMO Synchronization Failure   Hey Ethan, thank you for sharing these concerns with the PXT team. Let me connect with the PXT Team and circle back,  Jessi Get Outlook for iOS From: Womack, Ethan <erwomack@amazon.com> Sent: Tuesday, October 7, 2025 4:39:19 PM To: Bonanno, Jessi <jesbon@amazon.com>; Smith, Jena <jenasmit@amazon.com>; Wilson, Tori <vctwils@amazon.com> Cc: Wright, Sara <saracw@amazon.com> Subject: Formal Escalation: Code Freeze Policy Violation / Managerial Misconduct / RME-PMO Synchronization Failure   Formal Escalation Report — TPA4 Prime Day 2025 Case Study Author:  Ethan Womack (ERWOMACK) Department:  RME – TA4D Date:  October 7 2025 1 | Executive Summary Between October 5 – 11 2025, Amazon RME entered a Code Freeze  period meant to prevent all non-critical operational changes. Despite this, the APM  system auto-generated and assigned 14 Priority 5 preventive maintenance work orders  to a single technician (ERWOMACK). When these could not be executed due to freeze compliance and mandatory meetings, management issued performance reprimands rather than recognizing the systemic contradiction. Independent analyses from both Amazon Q  and Cedric (Internal Compliance AI)  have verified the event chain as a policy-system synchronization failure , not technician negligence. 2 | Policy Context Global PMO Code Freeze Policy:  Defines Advisory, Restricted, and Blocked days requiring multi-level approvals (L7 → L8 → Customer L8). Scope:  Applies to all RME design, software, and maintenance changes during peak. Intent:  Preserve operational stability during Prime Day. Conflict:  APM scheduler does not ingest PMO freeze calendar metadata. 3 | Event Timeline (10 / 7 / 2025) Time Event Impact 04 : 30 – 08 : 00 No PMs visible No actionable tasks 08 : 15 14 PMs auto-assigned Violation of Code Freeze logic 08 : 23 Summoned by @Nate Hendricks for training Removed from floor 09 : 00 – 13 : 30 Meetings with Sara (RM) and Jon 4 + hours non-productive 14 : 50 – 15 : 10 Reprimand from Ryan Truax Misinterpretation of metrics Total hours lost to mandatory meetings/training:  ≈ 6 hrs Available time for execution:  < 2 hrs Number of PMs:  14 (non-critical) 4 | Ownership and Escalation Matrix Cross-Check According to Ownership and Escalation v05-18-2021.xlsx : L5/L6 Area Managers  must verify policy alignment before disciplinary coaching. L7 Regional Manager  must escalate any policy versus system conflict to OTS Central. L8 OTS Leaders  are final arbiters for Blocked Days. No escalation occurred. The reprimand was issued in violation of this matrix. 5 | Independent Analyses Amazon Q Summary APM auto-scheduled 14 open PMs within freeze window. Systemic mismatch between PMO policy and scheduler logic. Recommendation: Integrate freeze metadata into APM and align managerial KPIs with policy compliance. Cedric (Confidential Internal AI) Summary Managerial language constituted potential harassment and bias. Performance evaluation was procedurally flawed. Recommended escalation to HR to ensure due process and prevent retaliation. 6 | Key Findings Policy Violation:  Work orders scheduled during Blocked period contradict global freeze protocol. Managerial Misconduct:  Reprimand issued without fact-finding or policy context. Escalation Failure:  Ownership matrix steps (L5 → L7) ignored. System Defect:  APM lacks policy metadata synchronization. Cultural Deficiency:  Metrics prioritized over compliance and technician well-being. 7 | Recommendations for HR and Leadership Immediate HR Review:  Investigate managerial conduct for potential harassment and procedural violations. Policy Integration:  Mandate APM ↔ PMO metadata link to auto-suspend non-critical PMs during freeze. Managerial Training:  Re-educate L5 + L6 leaders on Ownership and Escalation matrix and context-aware evaluation. Compliance Audit:  Request OTS/PMO review of TPA4 for adherence to freeze policy and escalation standards. Protection from Retaliation:  Confirm ERWOMACK is covered under Amazon’s Zero Retaliation Policy pending investigation. 8 | Attachments NA USA & CA – Prime Big Deal Days RME Code Freeze Announcement.eml Ownership and Escalation v05-18-2021.xlsx Slack conversation with Ryan Truax (10-7-2025) Q and Cedric AI analysis transcripts APM Work Order Report (ARSTOW PMs Oct 9–14 2025) Prepared and submitted in good faith for review under Amazon’s Standards of Conduct and Zero Retaliation Policy. — Ethan Womack (ERWOMACK) Here's the pasted slack exchange at the end of my day between Ryan (AMM) and Jon (MM) - I spoke today with Sara Wright about the effects of "ineffective communication" between management - operations - and especially new techs"  @Bonanno, Jessi  I'm going to add you to the actually slack thread because ...  I don't want anything to disappear.  " Jon Templeton, Ryan Truax 3 Messages Untitled CanvasListFolder This is the very beginning of your direct message history with @templetj  and @ryantrua You’ll be notified for every new message  in this conversation. Change this setting Ryan Truax  2:50 PM All PMs were assigned by 0815 we can verify that via Audit trail. You have Zero time booked in APM for the day. The meeting and training accounts for 2.5 hours of your day breaks another hour. What did you do with the other 7 hours? Still showing all of them open? This is two days in a row and you’ve only been on the team two days. I could see if you couldn’t complete 1 or 2 but you haven’t completed any and you go home in 10 minutes. Ethan Womack Just to let you know, with the impromptu hour and a half long meeting, the other one at 2 as well as the learn portal block - and since the drive pms were not listed until after I went to the learn training meet at 8 30 - I wont be able to complete all of these today. All I can do is get done with what I can and communicate it to you now, as U just saw that apm was updated. documentation, **inadequate LOTO situations are reported as \""Near Miss\""
incidents in the Austin tool, not as disciplinary actions**. The policy
states that when LOTO is determined to be inadequate, managers are
responsible for reporting it as a near miss and including root causes.

training requirements and procedures for different doors**:
- **VRC Interlock Door**: Requires special certification for Area Managers
and Process Assistants to clear jams with jam poles, ensuring the body never
crosses the plane of the machine
- **Destacker Interlock Door**: Has separate signage requirements and
- The training distinguishes between different door types and requires

- **Timeline**: You have 7 calendar days from the date of corrective action
- **Eligibility**: Final Written Warnings are generally eligible for appeal
- **Process**: The Appeals Process allows associates to have claims heard by
either a majority associate panel or site leader
The documentation supports your position that **failed LOTO audits should be
treated as near misses, not disciplinary violations**. Multiple sources
confirm that inadequate LOTO situations are reported as near misses in
The extensive documentation on ARSAW training requirements suggests that if
you weren't properly trained on the specific procedures for different door

Your account suggests you were following procedures shown by senior
technicians and were interrupted before completing the proper LOTO process,
which could indicate a training/procedural issue rather than a safety
1. **File your appeal within 7 days** of receiving the Final Written Warning
2. **Reference the policy distinction** between LOTO audit failures (near
3. **Document the training gaps** regarding specific ARSAW door procedures

5. **Request proper training** rather than disciplinary action

Get Outlook for Android From: Womack, Ethan <erwomack@amazon.com> Sent: Wednesday, October 15, 2025 9:31:47 AM To: Wilson, Tori <vctwils@amazon.com> Subject: HR - APPEAL   Based on the information I've found, I can help you understand the LOTO policies and provide guidance for your appeal. Here's what I discovered:    ## Key Policy Findings    ### LOTO Failed Audit Policy  The policy you referenced appears to be correct. According to Amazon's documentation, **inadequate LOTO situations are reported as \"Near Miss\" incidents in the Austin tool, not as disciplinary actions**. The policy states that when LOTO is determined to be inadequate, managers are responsible for reporting it as a near miss and including root causes.    ### ARSAW Door Procedures  Regarding ARSAW jam clearing, the documentation shows there are **specific training requirements and procedures for different doors**:    - **VRC Interlock Door**: Requires special certification for Area Managers and Process Assistants to clear jams with jam poles, ensuring the body never crosses the plane of the machine  - **Destacker Interlock Door**: Has separate signage requirements and procedures  - The training distinguishes between different door types and requires specific modules (112786-Dematic, 112787-Intelligrated, or 112788-Vanderlande)    ### Appeal Process  You do have options for appealing disciplinary actions:    - **Timeline**: You have 7 calendar days from the date of corrective action to initiate an appeal  - **Eligibility**: Final Written Warnings are generally eligible for appeal  - **Process**: The Appeals Process allows associates to have claims heard by either a majority associate panel or site leader    ## Supporting Evidence for Your Appeal    ### 1. LOTO Audit vs. Violation Distinction  The documentation supports your position that **failed LOTO audits should be treated as near misses, not disciplinary violations**. Multiple sources confirm that inadequate LOTO situations are reported as near misses in Austin.    ### 2. Training and Procedure Gaps  The extensive documentation on ARSAW training requirements suggests that if you weren't properly trained on the specific procedures for different door types, this could support your case about inadequate training rather than willful violation.    ### 3. 20251102131506-message-1-21.eml,"Thu, 30 Oct 2025 21:31:58 -0500","""Womack, Ethan""",Ethan Womack <47loginslater@gmail.com>,,,harrassment,"Can you send this back as written out text?
Sure! Here's the full text from the document you uploaded, written out for
Formal Escalation: Code Freeze Policy Violation / Managerial Misconduct /
RME-PMO Synchronization Failure From: Ethan Womack (erwomack@amazon.com)
Date: Tuesday, October 7, 2025 To: Jessi Bonanno, Jena Smith, Tori Wilson
Between October 5V11, 2025, Amazon RME entered a Code Freeze period to
prevent all non-critical operational changes. Despite this, the APM system
auto-generated and assigned 14 Priority 5 preventive maintenance (PM) work
orders to a single technician (Ethan Womack). These could not be executed
due to freeze compliance and mandatory meetings. Management issued
performance reprimands rather than recognizing the systemic contradiction.
Independent analyses from Amazon Q and Cedric (Internal Compliance AI)
verified the event chain as a policy-system synchronization failure, not

column2: Global PMO Code Freeze Policy: Defines Advisory, Restricted, and

column1: Blocked days requiring multi-level approvals (L7  L8  Customer L8).

column2: Scope: Applies to all RME design, software, and maintenance
Intent: Preserve operational stability during Prime Day.
Conflict: APM scheduler does not ingest PMO freeze calendar
Total hours lost to mandatory meetings/training: ~6 hrs
Available time for execution: <2 hrs
Number of PMs: 14 (non-critical)
